p: A congenital cholesteatoma is a keratinized squamous epithelial middle ear lesion that usually presents in young children who do not have a history of otitis media, middle ear surgery, or trauma. The presentation and progress of congenital cholesteatoma are quite different from those of acquired cholesteatoma. Congenital cholesteatomas commonly appear as pearl-like epidermoid cysts, mostly located in the antero-superior quadrant behind an intact tympanic membrane [ 1, 2]. These cholesteatomas can have invasive growth and cause osteolysis [ 3].
